entry.title: The Sound of Music, 1965 - ★★★★★
entry.content: Julie Andrews and Christopher Plummer are perfectly cast, and there isn’t a single wrong note, musically, lyrically, or emotionally. Robert Wise’s direction is masterful in its subtlety, guiding the film with a choreographed grace that matches its shifting tone.

entry.title: Day for Night, 1973 - ★★★★★
entry.content: There’s a rare sense of camaraderie here. You don’t feel like a voyeur peeking behind the scenes, you feel like you’re part of the crew. Truffaut himself slips into the film without vanity, and his voice, literally and figuratively, is felt throughout.

entry.title: Eye of the Needle, 1981 - ★★★
entry.content: Gone is the deep internal complexity of the book’s characters. What we get instead is a tight, suspenseful thriller with a focus on physical tension more than emotional depth. The espionage elements are still there, but this version is more about survival than subtlety.

entry.title: A Girl Cut in Two, 2007 - ★★★
entry.content: La Fille coupée en deux is carried largely by François Berléand’s complex, layered performance. Ludivine Sagnier, despite being the title character, plays with a rather limited emotional range. The editing deserves special mention: sharp and sometimes jarring, deliberately…

entry.title: Annie Hall, 1977 - ★★★★★
entry.content: The chemistry between Woody Allen and Diane Keaton reaches its absolute peak here. The script is one of the finest ever written for the screen. The editing, the use of flashbacks, time jumps, asides to the camera, even animated interludes, everything contributes to a cinematic…

entry.title: Manhattan, 1979 - ★★★★★
entry.content: Manhattan is more than a romantic comedy or a city portrait. It’s a film that hums with artistry, vulnerability, and the sad, sweet absurdity of longing. The music doesn’t just underscore the film, it becomes part of its soul. A masterpiece of mood and tone.

entry.title: Nothing Sacred, 1937 - ★★★★
entry.content: Lombard dazzles, as always, with her sharp comic instincts and she can play ingenue too. March plays the cynical straight man with just the right amount of exasperated flair. The script is loaded with biting wit, and every minute brims with laughter.

entry.title: Manhattan Murder Mystery, 1993 - ★★★★★
entry.content: The original Only Murders in the Building, Manhattan Murder Mystery is a perfect blend of real suspense and screwball energy. Diane Keaton is again at her absolute best here: jittery, curious, bold, and hysterically on edge. Alan Alda, Anjelica Huston, and Jerry Adler (also…
